TextView.android:text: - Pay attention to the tense of clues. If a definition terminates in –ing, –ed, or is a plural, the solution will usually take the same form.

- An exclamation mark is used to indicate that the whole clue must be considered as a literal definition of the answer. Take for instance the clue 'Some thought it an ice-breaker!' for TITANIC. There is no standard definition for the answer, but the meaning of the entire clue is intended to point towards it. However, note that some setters use the exclamation mark more as an indication of having come up with (in their opinion) a good or humorous clue.

- Think about different ways each word in the clue can be interpreted. 'Spanner' could refer to a tool or a to bridge. 'Layer' could refer to a coating or sheet of material, but could also be describing a bird which lays eggs. 'Tower' is a type of building but also a car pulling a trailer. In this example even the word 'number' can have an unexpected meaning.

- Because a typical cryptic clue describes its answer in detail and often more than once, the solver can usually have a great deal of confidence in the answer once it has been determined. The clues are 'self-checking'. This is in contrast to non-cryptic crossword clues which often have several possible answers and force the solver to use the crossing letters to distinguish which was intended.
